text: Mr. Spicer: Good afternoon.
Just before I came up I wanted to let you know
that we&#39;re monitoring the severe weather that&#39;s
going through Louisiana at this time.
The President&#39;s aware of the situation and is going
to be reaching out to local and state officials
throughout the day.
Also, yesterday evening the President concurred
with the FEMA administrator&#39;s
recommendation to approve Governor Bryant&#39;s request
to add public assistant to the previously issued
major disaster declaration in Mississippi.
Per the governor&#39;s request, public assistance
will be added for three counties: Forrest,
Lamar, and Perry.
Yesterday, the President had an amazing day at
MacDill Air Force Base where he met with leaders
of both Special Operations Command and Central
Command, and then had lunch with enlisted
service members thanking them for their service and
hearing the ideas that were on their mind.
The President announced his intent to make
historic financial investment in the armed
forces of the United States, showing the entire
world that America has the back of all those who
stand in defense of freedom.
As he has said many times before, the armed forces
are at the very center of our fight against radical
Islamic terrorism, and we must protect those
who protect us.
The President kicked off today with a listening
session of county sheriffs from around the country.
The President welcomed leaders from the National
Sheriff&#39;s Association to the White House and
pledged to work closely with all members of law
enforcement to keep the American people safe.
He assured the sheriffs that the Trump
administration will make every effort to stop drugs
and crime from flowing into the country, put an
end to the opioid epidemic, secure the
borders, keep terrorists out, and strengthen the
bonds between state, local, and federal law
enforcement agencies.
The sheriffs thanked the President for what they
described as his &quot;unprecedented level of
support for law enforcement&quot; and offered
their full backing of his border security and
immigration policies.
They expressed how encouraged they&#39;ve been by
the pro-law enforcement atmosphere that has swept
the country in the wake of the President&#39;s victory.
They also presented a letter on behalf of the
National Sheriff&#39;s Association thanking the
President for his &quot;recent show of support for law
enforcement, specifically on immigration and border
security issues&quot; and commending the President&#39;s
two executive orders for taking &quot;significant steps
to enhancing public safety.&quot; The group engaged
in a wide-ranging discussion about the
issues facing law enforcement, which the
sheriffs said was an opportunity they hadn&#39;t
been given under the previous administration.
The sheriffs closed the meeting by thanking the
President for defending the rule of law, and the
President took them in the oval office to honor them
and show his appreciation for their outstanding work
they do to keep our communities safe.
A list of the attendees is available for those
who are interested.
After that meeting, the President held another
listening session on how to best fix the VA.
It&#39;s a top priority for the President and this
administration to ensure that veterans get the care
they need, when and where they need it.
Tragically, many of our veterans are being failed
by a system that does not work.
This administration will reform and modernize the
VA under the leadership of Dr. Shulkin, creating a
culture of accountability that puts our veterans first.
The President welcomed the group to the Roosevelt
room and expressed his intention to take whatever
steps are necessary to improve healthcare access
and quality for our heroic veterans.
Ms. Tiffany Smiley, the wife of a veteran who was
blinded by an IED, detailed her family&#39;s
difficulty and experience with the VA&#39;s healthcare
system and offered suggestions to how it
could be improved.
The President, VA secretary-designate
Dr. Shulkin, and a group of healthcare expert and
veterans advocates, including Ike and Laura
Perlmutter, engaged in a wide-ranging discussion on
reforming the VA so that the needs of
veterans come first.
The experts discussed private-sector solutions
and innovations that could be used to improve the VA.
The President praised the secretary designate for
his commitment to veterans and thanked the group
for their willingness to serve and do what was best
for our veterans.
The plan to meet on a regular basis to discuss
their collective efforts to improve the VA and its
healthcare system.
Also this afternoon, the Vice President had a big
day on Capitol Hill where he cast the historic,
deciding vote for Secretary of
Education Betsy DeVos.
The President believes strongly that our nation&#39;s
success depends on education of our students,
and Betsy DeVos has devoted her nearly three
decades of her time and talent to promoting
educational opportunity.
As secretary, she will ensure that every student
has access to a good school, whether it&#39;s
public, private, parochial, charter,
or any other kind.
The fact that we had to get to the point where the
Vice President had to be pulled in to overcome the
Democrats historic and partisan logjam with the
President&#39;s qualified nominee is another glaring
reminder of the unprecedented obstruction
that Senate Democrats
have engaged in throughout this process.
The American people sent a strong message when they
elected President Trump in November.
They&#39;re fed up with business as
usual in Washington.
Democrats in the Senate should expect that voters
will remember how they stood in the way of the
President in acting an agenda that put
him into office.
Last week I noted the President had a fair
amount of cabinet-level appointees awaiting a full
vote by the Senate.
We&#39;re looking forward to seeing more of the
President&#39;s pick to lead agencies and departments
confirmed in the upcoming week, despite these
childish tactics of the Democrats in the Senate
who would rather keep the failed status quo than
allowing to put the President&#39;s people in place.
Also on the hill today, Judge Gorsuch continues a
full week of meetings with Republican
and Democratic senators.
Yesterday he met with Senators Tester and Feinstein.
Today he will meet with Senators Sasse, Schumer,
Crapo, and Thune.
The President is looking forward to a full hearing
for the judge followed by an up or down vote on
this incredibly qualified nominee.
At this moment, the President is meeting with
Congressman Jason Chaffetz to discuss how to work
together to enact his reform agenda.
Later this afternoon, the President will meet with
Secretary of State Tillerson.
The President was obviously pleased to
welcome and confirm, swear in Secretary Tillerson in
the oval office last week, and he&#39;s pleased the
secretary is now able to bring his unique skill set
and deep insights to the important work of the
State Department.
Following his discussion with Secretary Tillerson,
the President will have calls with Prime Minister
Rajoy of Spain and President Erdogan of Turkey.
We&#39;ll, of course, have readouts of both of those
calls when they&#39;re completed.
This evening the President will host young officers
from the United States Army Special Forces
Qualification Course in the oval office.
As the President said yesterday, members of our
military and their families are
our nation&#39;s heroes.
It is one of his top priorities to ensure that
the men and women of our armed forces have the
tools, equipment, and resources they need to
execute their mission successfully.
The President&#39;s looking forward to conveying his
gratitude and support to these young,
brave captains.
Later this evening around 6:00, the 9th Circuit
Court will hold oral arguments per its
order from yesterday.
I want to quickly run down what we can expect
to happen tonight.
A career attorney from the Department of Justice will
present an argument in defense of the
President&#39;s order.
And to be clear, all that&#39;s at issue tonight is
the hearing is an interim decision on whether the
President&#39;s order is enforced or not until the
case is heard on the actual merits of the order.
It&#39;s a simple status quo versus
anti-status quo decision.
This is just like the case in Boston which started as
a temporary restraining order.
There, once we were able to explain our position,
the court lifted the order and held that the
President&#39;s executive order could take effect.
As I&#39;ve stated before, 8 U.S.
Code 1182 gives the President constitutional
authority for this executive order.
It says, &quot;Whenever the President finds that the
entry of any aliens or of any class of aliens into
the United States would be detrimental to the
interests of the United States, he may by
proclamation, and for such period as he shall deem
necessary, suspend the entry of all aliens or any
class of aliens as immigrants or
non-immigrants, or impose on the entry of aliens any
restrictions which he may deem appropriate.&quot; We look
forward to a final decision on the
merits of this soon.
Looking ahead, I know a few of you have been
asking about more details on Prime Minister Abe&#39;s
visit later this week.
As previously announced, he will visit the White
House for meetings on the 10th of February.
The President has also invited him down to
Mar-a-Lago, and the two leaders will travel there
for the weekend.
This is a testament to the importance the United
States places on the bi-lateral relationship,
and the strength of our alliance, and the deep
economic ties between the United States and Japan.
Needless to say, the President&#39;s looking very
much forward to welcoming the New England Patriots
to the White House to celebrate their fifth
world championship.
It was obviously a spectacular game.
Lastly, we have our eyes on Kabul today following
the tragic suicide bombing that killed at least 19
Afghan civilians and wounded 14.
Just this morning, General Flynn spoke with the
Afghan national security advisor to reaffirm our
continued support for Afghanistan and for our
strategic partnership.
We condemn this cowardly attack in the strongest
possible terms, and we commend the Afghan
security forces for their rapid response.
We also reaffirm our support to the Afghan
government as they work to defend their people and
against enemies of peace.
And with that, I&#39;ll take your questions.
The Press: Sean, the list of 78 terrorist attacks
that you released.
It looked like it had been prepared well in advance.
I mean, but was that already on hand when
President Trump made his comments or did you
do it afterwards?
Why&#39;d you release it?
Mr. Spicer: Well, I think the answer was we had been
getting questions as to what the
President&#39;s remarks were.
We wanted to be very clear that there are a lot of
examples between 2014 and 2015 that have occurred,
and many of them haven&#39;t gotten the attention
that they have deserved.
It&#39;s becoming too often that we&#39;re seeing these
attacks not get the spectacular attention
that they deserve.
And I think it undermines the understanding of the
threat that we face around this country.
The reasons the President&#39;s acting in so
many of the way that he has with executive order
and otherwise, the discussions that he had
down at CENTCOM and SOCOM yesterday, are because he
cares about making sure that we don&#39;t have attacks
in this country, that we&#39;re protected, that
we&#39;re ahead of the curve.
And I think what we need to do is remind people
that the earth is a very dangerous place these days.
That ISIS is trying to do us harm, and that the
President&#39;s commitment is to keep this country safe.
And I think part of this is to make sure that the
American people are reminded how prevalent
some of these attacks are and how much time and
attention they have or have not gotten.
But, more importantly, that they understand the
unwavering commitment that the President has and the
actions that he will take to keep the country safe.
The Press: Just to be clear, was the list
put together after his comments?
Mr. Spicer Yes, yes.
The Press: After his comments?
Mr. Spicer Yes.
The Press: Sean, Sean.
Mr. Spicer Trey.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
On the call with Turkish President Erdogan later
today, does President Trump intend to discuss
plans for Syrian safe zones, and does the
President expect Turkey to help create those zones?
Mr. Spicer I think we&#39;ll have a read out
for you on that.
I don&#39;t want to get ahead of the two leader&#39;s calls.
Alexus, Real Clear Politics.
The Press: Sean, I have two questions for you.
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
The Press: You were mentioning that voters are
going to remember how senators voted on the
President&#39;s Cabinet nominees.
Two Republicans voted against Betsy DeVos,
Senators Collins and Murkowski.
Did the President reach out to either of them, and
will he not forget what Republicans did in
that particular nominee situation?
Mr. Spicer I think that - look - the President&#39;s
been very clear.
It&#39;s not Republicans that have stood in the way of
this nomination of all of these
qualified individuals.
It&#39;s been Democrats that have stalled over
and over again.
Not attending hearings.
Trying to use every delay tactic possible.
It&#39;s those people that have a problem, and I
think that&#39;s the message that the party has missed
on the Democratic side, which would - and I don&#39;t
think that - wouldn&#39;t paint that with a broad
brush, because I think it&#39;s Senate Democrats,
frankly, that haven&#39;t gotten the message.
The Press: But has he reached out to them?
Mr. Spicer Our team has been in contact with all
- with the entire Senate team -
The Press: Okay.
Mr. Spicer - to make sure that they understand and
that they&#39;ve had visits as requested.
But we&#39;ve been in constant contact with the Senate,
the members of the Senate, their staffs.
Our legislative team has had an extremely robust
schedule of meetings with their teams to make these
nominees available to them, but I think the
broader issue - again, and with all due respect - I
think it&#39;s interesting that we&#39;re focusing on the
votes of two Republicans.
When you look at the spectrum of antics that
have gone on in the Democrats.
I mean, the tactics that they have done over and
over and over again to delay, not show
up to hearings.
You know, filibuster to the extent that they can.
Run the clock out.
It&#39;s not Republicans that have a problem here, Alexus.
It&#39;s the Democrats that continue to do this.
The Press: My other question has to do with
the President&#39;s remarks about the Affordable Care
Act in his interview on Sunday.
Because he indicated in his response in that
interview that he thought that the repeal in place
was going to take longer - perhaps into 2018 - can
you clarify whether he is frustrated about this,
what he is doing about the timing, because of course,
voters who sent him here were anticipating that
this might move faster than he was conveying in
the interview?
Mr. Spicer Well, I think, luckily, and you saw
Speaker Ryan&#39;s comments earlier today, I think we
can have this done legislatively sooner
rather than later, but I think the implementation
of a lot of the pieces may take a little bit longer.
It&#39;s a big, big bill that the Democrats passed.
As you recall, they told us we could read it after
they passed it.
We&#39;re now going through this to make sure that we
do this in a very responsible way to make
sure that healthcare, which is so vital to so
many Americans and their families, is preserved
while we put a new system in place that both lowers
cost and increases accessibility.
But the President, I think, is very encouraged
by the commitment and work that&#39;s going on the Hill
to make sure that we get this thing replaced as
quick as possible.
Fred Lucas.
Fred.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
The Press: Yeah.
One thing to ask.
Actually a follow up to that.
Speaker Ryan has actually said, and I&#39;m quoting,
&quot;With Obamacare, you can&#39;t tinker at the margins and
repair it; you can&#39;t; it&#39;s a collapsing law.&quot;
Do you agree with that in that you can&#39;t build on
what&#39;s already there.
We have to get rid of the entire law?
Mr. Spicer: I think what we&#39;re focused on
is the end solution.
And I think we&#39;ve been very clear over and over
again, the President is going to repeal and
replace it, and that what Americans will get at the
end of this is a healthcare solution that,
as I&#39;ve said before over and over again, is going
to give them a lower cost health solution
with more options.
That&#39;s what they were promised in
the first place.
That&#39;s what we can give, and I think the President
being able to approach this in the business-like
manner that he&#39;s done so successfully in the past
is going to ensure that he negotiates prices, that we
look at those business-like practice,
force competition amongst states and other things
that will help lower cost once and for all and
provide that competition.
The Press: On Iran - on Iran sanctions, does the
President have any concerns about the fact
that Adam Szubin is the acting Secretary in
terms of implementing those sanctions?
Mr. Spicer No.
We implemented them.
They went off without a hitch.
Fred.
Fred.
I mean, John Decker.
The Press: Thanks so much, Sean.
As you know, the President has spoke over the weekend
on Twitter and criticized the federal judge
appointed by George W.
Bush who imposed that nationwide restraining order.
He called him a &quot;so-called judge&quot;.
Is the President, as it relates to the arguments -
I know that you&#39;re confident that the
arguments that will be presented this evening -
is he prepared to accept an adverse ruling by the
9th Circuit Court of Appeals?
Mr. Spicer There&#39;s no question that the
President respects the judicial branch in its
ruling, but I think there&#39;s no way - I just
read off the US code on that - I don&#39;t think
there&#39;s any other way that you can interpret that,
that the President has the discretion to do what&#39;s
necessary to keep this country safe.
And I think that&#39;s-that&#39;s his concern, frankly,
right now that when the law is such as it is that
anyone could interpret that any other way.
I think he feels confident just like in the ruling in
Boston that we&#39;re going to prevail on this on the
merits of the case because it is done so in a
very lawful way.
Katherine.
The Press: Will the administration take a
position on the Israeli legislation to legalize
the thousands of West Bank settlements.
Last week, obviously, was building settlements?
Mr. Spicer As I mentioned last week, I don&#39;t want to
get too far ahead of this, but Prime Minister
Netanyahu will be here on the 15th.
I think that will be obviously a
topic of discussion.
Right now, I don&#39;t want to get ahead of that.
Charlie.
The Press: Sean.
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
Charlie.
The Press: Just a quick question: any response to
the calls for impeachment by Representative
Maxine Waters?
Mr. Spicer No.
Hunter Walker.
I mean, I would just say - look - I think - look - it
is the President is doing everything he can to move
this country forward, and I think whether it&#39;s the
Democrats and the Senate who are trying to stall
these nominees or these political stunts on the
House side, the bottom line is that, by and
large, you see the support that the President is
receiving for his policies throughout the country,
and it&#39;s because I think people recognize a) the
business as usual is over, and that the President&#39;s
commitment to both keeping this country safe, growing
the economy, and creating jobs is something that is
welcome by all Americans regardless of party.
I think when you see stuff like that it really just
shows that they missed the message that voters sent
this past November.
Hunter Walker.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
CNN reportedly declined to interview Kellyanne Conway
on Sunday because of the - because of questions about
her credibility.
Is the White House willing to offer alternative
representatives for the networks that refuse to
work with specific spokespeople?
Mr. Spicer I-I-I - well, frankly - I think that -
my understanding is that they retracted that,
they&#39;ve walked it back, or denied it.
However you want to put it, I don&#39;t care.
But I think Kellyanne is a very trusted aid
of the President.
I think to - for any characterization
otherwise is insulting.
I don&#39;t think if they choose to not work with
someone, that&#39;s up to them, but I think we&#39;re
going to continue to put out key leaders to this
administration including Kellyanne that can
articulate the President&#39;s policies and agenda.
Katie Pavlich.
The Press: [inaudible] for this question.
Is President Trump planning to ask the Senate
to expedite legislation for the split firing of
bad VA employees?
Mr. Spicer: I think the President&#39;s commitment, as
you heard both during the campaign, and as he&#39;s
talked to Dr. Shulkin, is to make sure that we&#39;re
providing the best care, and if there&#39;s things that
are an impediment to that care being offered up or
reformed, then he is going to make sure that we enact
policies internally that make sure that people who
are not doing their job not servicing veterans, we
can figure out how to expedite that process.
But the idea that we&#39;re sitting around having a
discussion about personnel inhibiting the care that
veterans deserve really does not bode well for the
reflection that we want on this country.
I mean, the people who have served this nation -
we should be bending over backward to make sure that
the benefits and the care and the services that
they, frankly, earned is something that is given
the highest priority, and it&#39;s something that the
President remains highly committed to.
Miriam Burgess.
Miriam.
The Press: Hey.
Hi.
[inaudible] he is going to speak later today with the
Spanish leader, Mariano Rajoy -
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
The Press: - and I would like to know how President
Trump sees the relation with Spain, and what are
the main issues they are going to discuss in the
phone call?
Mr. Spicer So, I&#39;m not going to - we&#39;ll have a
read out after the call, but I imagine they&#39;re
going to talk about a shared commitment to
defeating ISIS, and that they&#39;ll discuss our
bilateral relationship and reaffirm our company
to the countries.
We will have a readout on that call with Spain as we
will with all the countries and all
the other leaders that we will talk to.
And we have in the past.
So, I don&#39;t want to get too far ahead of it, but I
would imagine that the current relationship that
we have with Spain and our commitment to ISIS will be
at the forefront of that.
Maria Penna.
Maria.
The Press: Yeah.
Here.
Saying here.
It&#39;s kind of loud in here.
So it&#39;s a two-part question: one, can you
confirm whether or not the White House has accepted
the credentials of the new Mexican ambassador,
Geronimo Gutierrez?
And, also, Representative Mike Rogers, I believe,
this morning said that he plans to introduce a bill
to impose a two percent tax on all remittances
that Mexicans send to their country to
pay for the wall.
Would the President rally behind that bill?
Mr. Spicer So, first, I have to get back to you
on the ambassador&#39;s credentials.
We can check with the Department of State and
figure that out.
I don&#39;t know that right off the top of my head,
and I&#39;m not going to comment - we don&#39;t put out
statements of administration policy
until the bill has gone through the process.
Haley.
The Press: Two questions for you.
One, following up on healthcare, the President,
as you know, campaigned for 18 months on replacing
the Affordable Care Act.
Where is his plan?
Mr. Spicer Well, he&#39;s working with Congress.
I just asked for that - answered that question,
but he&#39;s working with Speaker Ryan, leaders - I
mean, you&#39;re acting like -
The Press: But the specifics of it though?
Does he owe the American people something now?
Mr. Spicer And I think that&#39;s he&#39;s been very
clear that he owes the American people a result
that&#39;s going to lower cost and provide more access.
That&#39;s what he continues to work with Speaker Ryan on.
I think the Speaker was very clear on it.
That they&#39;re having meetings, both
legislatively and at the principle level to make
sure that this gets done, and I think that, as you
heard Speaker Ryan, we continue to be optimistic
about getting this thing completed by this year.
It&#39;s a mammoth bill what they passed and did it,
and I think we&#39;ve got to make sure that
we do this right.
We don&#39;t want to end up with the same result that
the Democrats did.
They rushed it through; no one was able to read the
bill, and premiums have skyrocketed; access and
options have gone down.
We need to make sure that we don&#39;t do this in a way
that&#39;s going to end up with the same result.
John Roberts.
The Press: The other question for you, though,
Sean, on Yemen.
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
The Press: I did say two.
Mr. Spicer Yes, you did.
The Press: One of the world&#39;s most wanted
terrorists is now taunting President Trump calling
him a fool after that raid.
Mr. Spicer Right.
The Press: Any response from the White House, and
do you still stand by your characterization -
Mr. Spicer Well, I-I -
The Press: - characterization that it
was a successful raid?
Mr. Spicer Absolutely.
That-that - he was not - that-that-the raid that
was conducted in Yemen
was an intelligence-gathering raid.
That&#39;s what it was.
It was highly successful.
It achieved the purpose it was going to get, saved
the loss of life that we suffered and the
injuries that occurred -
The Press: So you&#39;re going back on reporting
that he was a target?
Mr. Spicer Absolutely.
He was not - the goal of the raid was
intelligence-gathering, and that&#39;s what we
received, and that&#39;s what we got.
That&#39;s why we can deem it a success.
John Roberts.
The Press: If-if - and another, I know that you
believe that you have a good case on the
marriage temporary restraining order?
If the President does not prevail the 9th Circuit
Court of Appeals, will he take this to the
Supreme Court, and -
Mr. Spicer Well, let&#39;s see what we got.
I mean -
The Press: - is he -
Mr. Spicer He&#39;s made it clear that he -
The Press: - can I, can I just finish?
Mr. Spicer Yeah, you can.
The Press: Thank you.
Mr. Spicer I&#39;m sorry.
The Press: And is he concerned that if this
does go to the Supreme Court with his current 4-4
make-up that this temporary restraining
order may become a little more permanent?
Mr. Spicer Well, remember that tonight is about just
a restraining order.
We&#39;re not - right - I understand, but I think
that it&#39;s important to explain this to everyone,
John, because I know you get it and so many other -
but I-I just want to make sure that we&#39;re - tonight
is about the restraining order.
It has nothing to do with the merits of the case.
And that&#39;s why I think we feel confident.
The question is does the restraining order
get lifted or not?
But, regardless of what happens tonight, the
merits of the case still need to be to discuss, and
I think the merits of the case, as they were in
Boston, were ones that we feel very confident on,
because the law is crystal clear on this.
The President has the authority to do this.
It was done so in an interagency process that
ensured that all the appropriate
people were consulted.
We went through that with flying colors.
I have zero concern that, at the end of the day,
we will be fine.
It&#39;s just a question of going through the process.
The Press; And I get all that -
Mr. Spicer Okay.
As you pointed out
The Press: - but if he does not prevail at the
9th Circuit, will he take this to the Supreme Court?
Mr. Spicer I&#39;m not going to get - let&#39;s see
where it goes first.
I think our goal right now is to get to a point
where we can argue it on the merits.
We feel confident based on how the court has reacted
in Massachusetts that we&#39;re going to be
good on the merits.
Jonathan Swan.
The Press: Sean, thanks for the question.
Mr. Spicer Yeah.
The Press: Does President Trump still plan to
immediately terminate President Obama&#39;s
executive [inaudible]?
Mr. Spicer With respect to what?
Dock and doppa?
The Press: Dock and Doppa.
Mr. Spicer I&#39;ve said this before.
We&#39;ll have further updates on that - I-I understand.
Go ahead.
The Press: Yeah.
It&#39;s just - in the thing it said
&quot;immediately terminate&quot; -
Mr. Spicer I understand that, and I&#39;ve said
before, the President will have further updates on
both dock and doppa very shortly.
We&#39;ve been very clear on immigration what the
President&#39;s priorities would be.
As you heard Secretary Kelly testify in front of
Congress today, there&#39;s going to be continued
progress on the wall and on immigration as a whole.
So we&#39;re going to have plenty of time to address
this - right now, he&#39;s trying to do it in a very
systematic way in accordance to where we
find the biggest problems, and so he&#39;s been very
clear in the past that those who are in this
country that pose a threat to us or with a criminal
record are where his priorities are going to be
first and foremost.
And we&#39;re going to move through the rest of the
folks who are in this country illegally.
Sarah.
The Press: Thank you, Sean.
Back to the Iran.
